article_title: Health-Care Overhaul Could Bring Profit and Pain for Medical Device Industry, Stryker CEO Says
article_text:
The rollout Tuesday of new health-insurance exchanges may bring both profit and pain to companies like Stryker Corp., one of the world's largest makers of medical devices and supplies, with sales of $8.65 billion last year.

Expanded coverage could spur more patients to replace creaky joints with Stryker's knee and hip implants, but the company also faces a 2.3% excise tax on U.S. device sales. Device makers have strenuously opposed...

twitter.description: Stryker CEO Kevin Lobo says the rollout of health-insurance exchanges may bring both profit and pain to medical-device makers. Expanded coverage could spur more patients to replace creaky joints with Stryker's knee and hip implants, but the company also faces a 2.3% excise tax on U.S. device sales.
twitter.creator: @joewalkerWSJ

article_summary:
Device makers have strenuously opposed...
The rollout Tuesday of new health-insurance exchanges may bring both profit and pain to companies like Stryker Corp., one of the world's largest makers of medical devices and supplies, with sales of $8.65 billion last year.
Expanded coverage could spur more patients to replace creaky joints with Stryker's knee and hip implants, but the company also faces a 2.3% excise tax on U.S. device sales.
